content.body: o_O lol at hybi
o_O indeed
they even want to remove the paragraph that says to send feedback to the hybi list!
someone just sent me a mail saying that they weren't receiving mail from the mailing list
they didn't say which mailing list...
oops
also, clearly it's too late, explaining people that whatwg.org is not nytimes.com is really not all that interesting
is quite lost.
TabAtkins: go left
goes left, and walks off the Cliff of Comprehension.
yeah, nn :) gonna spec the scroll event tomorrow
hopefully I remember what I just figured out
i smiled a litte when I read annevk's statement about not being the NY times site :)
Definitely.  ^_^
If you're reading the spec using IE6, You're Doing It Wrong(tm).
sweet kittens
i got the main bucket down to only mail that's about a month old, about 300 mails
and there's about 300 mails in the buckets that are new features delayed for various reasons
but the pile is at 900 mails
and i was like, where are all the other 300 mails?
turns out they're ALL ABOUT VIDEO
Work's cut out for you, then.
video on the web will never take off anyway.  just a fad, i'm afraid.
I wonder if you could make a web site which is entirely rendered through <video>
with live streaming of the page generated on the server
javascript+canvas?
using Web Sockets to transmit user input to the server
server-side canvas, transcoded to video and piped to the browser
cheeser: Nah, that's not thin client and is therefore uncool
Got to do all the rendering in the cloud
heh
was actually thinking of writing a websocket based irc client.
because i'm dumb that way.
cheeser: you should write an irc-based websocket client
heh
That'd be good when you want to write an efficient user-friendly web-based frontend to the IRC-based control system of a botnet
and the world definitely needs better botnet tools.
abarth: Man, are you trying to get sites hacked now? :P
gsnedders: ?
ah
i see :)
greetings
yo
Why did we add the sec-websocket-protocol header anyway?
Hixie: ^^^
how do you mean?
as opposed to what?
as opposed to WebSocket-Protocol? (i.e. why the sec-?)
or the entire protocol negotiation thing at all?
sorry, I mean the protocol negotiation -- what is the use case?
it's for when we are in a situaton where there's a dozen different IM protocols, and there are IM clients that can support many
and the user just gives a hostname
(and port and so on)
the client can just say "i speak all these subprotocols"
I see. Why not just handle that in application space?
the protocols would all have to do it in the same way to do it in the app space
so for example, if you invent a new protocol that just starts off with expecting the client says FOO, you can't detect that
except by just trying to connect with many differnet protocols, etc
which becomes hellish
The way people use network protocols now is with apriori knowledge
"I know there's an http server on example.org port 3232, so connect and download a web page."
at the TCP level, yeah
I mean, when I type  "http://example.org:3232" into my web browser, we don't depend on any tcp-level protocol negotiation
indeed
it's one of the reasons we've had so many problems with websockets
and why we're using HTTP's Upgrade mechanism
fair enough

I'm not particularly against it; I just have this feeling like its opened the flood gates to people wanting some giant meta protocol for negotiating everything with some super-complicated framing/handshake scheme
I mean, my default response to things like multiplexing is "do it in the app level."
*shrug*
What is our current stance on reverse proxy traversal -- "rewrite the proxy" ?
mcarter: depends on the reverse proxy
mcarter: from the spec's point of view, reverse proxies are part of the server
Hixie, shouldn't NPN also obsolete usage of the other handshake in part?
thought that was part of the appeal
annevk5: that seems like it would make transitioning to TLS a pain
annevk5: the current system, you just stick it on the front.
i guess it depends on how you see it
but if you do it like this you are not getting rid of the additional roundtrip?
annevk5: yes, that is a sad problem with TLS
I thought the whole idea of using NPN was to prevent that
otherwise there's presumably not much point in doing it
(though I'm not 100% sure... NPN seems to require a three-way handshake anyway, so maybe the WebSocket handshake only adds a single additional round-trip?)
well it makes it impossible to have a cross-protocol attack
wonders if abarth is around
which is a significant aid
you still need the WebSocket handshake for lots of other things
like opting into extensions, the origin model, etc
I wonder if the TLS/NPN handshake can carry whatever information would be in the HTTP-based WebSocket handshake
it sounded like that was the idea
Ian Fette keeps making more complicated frame proposals :/
I am not sure why he thinks random reserved bits in the header are helpful
Hmm, I see I am getting all the mail from yesterday
abarth: actually, ping here instead
The first screenful is about 70% [hybi] and 30% [whatwg]
abarth: when you have a moment, i would like to make http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10213 your proposal rather than mine :-)
hmm, scroll* is slightly more complicated it seems
hmm, maybe not
Hixie: sorry, i've had a bit too much to drink tonight
Hixie: i'd be happy to look at it tomorrow
Hixie: that bug looks like URL parsing, which i'm happy to have be my problem
abarth: cool
abarth: Well, getting people to write IRC clients for Web sockets, I bet you some sites are going to fail to do proper authâ€¦
hmm, scrollIntoView seems rather complex
A blog post on the BBC about the "split" between W3C and WHAT WG http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/bbcinternet/2010/08/html5_open_standards_and_the_b.html The quoted source... Shelley. :-/
I hope my license fee didn't pay for that drivel.
and lastweekinhtml5 lol
is trollweek still going?
Jesus
dunno, but that bbc blog post links to something on it
"Erik Huggers is Director of BBC Future Media & Technology" haha
I wonder if I should register just to post a comment
glad we have sane people in NL running gov-sponsored media
well, somewhat saner
The BBC is generally quite awesome and it is sad when they fuck up
I'm glad the small bit of gov-sponsored media in the US is irrelevant
they make a lot of good shows
so that when I see poor journalism I can simply refrain from giving my money to the responsible organization
I love that the trollweek link is hyperlinked to the text "Professional integrity"
That was quite mystifying
yeah, this is quite a joke
apparently, professional integrity calls for a great deal of anatomical photography
Maybe this guy *is* MLW ;)
hmm
Safari does not support scrollIntoView?
Opera in a vastly different way from Mozilla
and only Gecko dispatches a scroll event
interop win
no wonder hixie asks me to take over
but chrome does it like Firefox
hmm
maybe WebKit recently fixed something
haha. I find it ironic that the link to MLW says "Professional integrity", which is something that MLW doesn't have.
we certainly have a scrollIntoView method
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/589 was my basic test
it "tests" whether scrolling happens and whether an event is dispatched on Document
clearly registering rel values is nigh-on impossible
this is exactly the problem with the IANA registries, they don't reflect actual practice making it harder to make informed decisions
what is the process for registering links relationships in the IANA registry?
Take one newborn goat and one full moon
Arm yourself with a dagger made from unicorn horn
Sacrifice the goat in a pool of virgin tears under the light of the full moon
There will then be a committe decision on whether to accept your relation or not
wow
Latest BBC news: WHATWG intends to sacrifice goats
I doubt it'll be as popular as that news story about the man marrying his goat
Unless, of course, that's the goat we sacrifice
"[Link relationship] Registration requests should be sent to the [TBD]@ietf.org mailing list" -- http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-nottingham-http-link-header-10#section-6.2.1
so it's currently not possible to send in a registration request
so for scrollIntoView() Chrome/Firefox also scroll the outer frame but Opera does not
can anyone check the link I pasted before in IE9?
IE9 does the same as Gecko/WebKit
which indeed is different from Opera
ta
I wonder if an event is dispatched in each document that performs scrolling behavior
and presumably for RTL content rules might be slightly different, hmm
it would be in Firefox
we also dispatch non-bubbling "scroll" events to overflow:auto/scroll elements that are scrolled by scrollIntoView
that makes sense
is multi-document not an issue for cross-origin?
even just the scrolling somehow triggered by a subframe seems suboptimal
it hasn't come up
maybe some enterprising miscreant could figure something out
it should probably at least not work for <iframe> with sandbox set
I guess I should probably define something like "scroll element to x,y" and "scroll document to x,y" which do the relevant "alignment" and event dispatching
or would some other model make more sense?
no, that's more or less how it's implemented
annevk5: about the offset* properties ... honestly, I don't want to touch those with a ten-foot pole
dhyatt said something similar about the HTML parser in WebKit
but they should match Gecko more or less now
it would be great if we could converge on something interoperable, but with ten years of non-interoperable behavior, and Web pages sniffing, it's just too fragile
apart from something related to the root element I think, where they match WebKit/Opera
annevk5: people don't emit different HTML based on UA sniffing
at least, not very often
plus, we've interoperated pretty well on common cases
which is why people don't have to UA-sniff
the situation with offset is ... less good
yeah :/
but I don't want people to have UA sniff forever and make it hard for new UAs either
if we were able to converge offset behavior, then authors could remove sniffing and rewrite their offset code paths to use a single code path
OR they could just rewrite those code paths to use getClientRects/getBoundingClientRect, right now
I'm not convinced it's worth investing in the former option
well, not every UA is sniffed for
and although we try to convince authors to do the right thing... it's usually a somewhat hopeless cause
whatever you specced, if it was implemented by all browsers, would lead to a lot of sites being broken for a lot of users
and I'm not sure who would be helped
so what does a new UA do?
I guess it gets an even longer UA string
new UAs would have to deal with a) new sites, which are using getClientRects anyway, so no issue and b) old sites, which haven't updated their code anyway so whatever you specced is irrelevant
I think the situation is somewhat less hopeless than you paint it
as Firefox / WebKit do the same for most tests (apart that root element test)
and Opera has two issues because of not following Firefox / WebKit
and new-IE follows Firefox mostly
IE changed their behavior?
hmm
(this does not take into account the <table> issue though)
they did several times afaik
ok
time to get expenses done before accounting leaves
guess scrollintoview will have to wait
thanks for all this
Hi, has there been any discussion recently regarding tri-state checkboxes?
darkangel: What kind of discussion?
'indeterminate' was added to the spec some time ago to support that
Philip`: Discussion of its possible inclusion in HTML5.
^ Really? Is that an attribute?
Use <input type=checkbox> then set input.indeterminate = true
With JS?
See http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/number-state.html#checkbox-state
Yes
'indeterminate' is an IE-compat feature, it's not a great APPI
Ah, it's older than I remembered
http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/commit-watchers-whatwg.org/2008/001807.html
Philip`: It would be best to be able to use an attribute, something like: <input type="checkbox" tristate="true" />
I don't really get the point of indeterminate, it behaves exactly the same (I know, that is mentioned in the spec).
Lachy: There?
yes
Lachy: Hello. What was the result of your discussion about tri-state checkboxes back in 2007? (http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/html-wg/20070914)
darkangel: It doesn't look the same, and indeterminate can be used for validation
the result was what's in the spec now, which occured after the discovery of the indeterminate property in IE
"If the element is required and its checkedness is false, then the element is suffering from being missing."
Poor element has to suffer because of the user's negligence
Lachy: But that's visual only, only two states can be determined on the server, right?
yes
Lachy: Then it's rather pointless IMHO. What if I want an explicit yes/no/no selection?
You control what state the checkbox is in when it enters indeterminate state
use radio buttons.
or <select>
If you can't make a sensible default, can't use client side validation, there's <select> and radio buttons
Lachy: ^ It forces a user to make a selection if the field is required.
Or just two checkboxes :)
Imagine a tree of checkboxes for preferences or access control ... would it look nice (or be easy to view) if each item had three radio buttons?
If it's actually tristate, yes
allow/deny/no rule
when you have a tree like that, the indeterminate state of a parent checkbox is determined based on the selected state of its children
But you might as well use selects, that way it's crystal clear what state it is in
Look here ... http://www.jstree.com/documentation/checkbox
I was planning on using this script, not realising they had built-in support for tri-state ...
But that just shows the need.
Well, it seems like you'd want a custom widget there so you can control what the indeterminate state looks like
But for pure functionality, indeterminate should work fine
Just make checked=false when you set indeterminate=true
Alternatively, you could just add a full-featured tree widget to HTML5. :D
It's not impossible, but it won't happen for a few years at least, while browsers implement what's already waiting
right
Workshiva: I would suggest the indeterminate state be no value submitted, checked=1, unchecked=2.
I don't know for sure, but I suspect there is content out there that depends on indeterminate submitting a value
^ unchecked=0 I mean.
It differs from the current 2-state checkbox, however you would have to opt-in using an attribute.
Existing content or future content?
Existing
Existing content would be unaffected.
You would have to use: <input type="checkbox" tristate="true" />
Then it makes more sense to make it a separate type
It doesn't seem very compatible at all
You mean <input type="tristate-checkbox" />
Yeah, plus some bikeshedding on the exact type
bikeshedding?
we're planning on adding that tree widget at some point so maybe it isn't needed?
look for <datagrid> in older drafts
it will come back at some point
annevk5: Will it be a combined tree/datagrid control?
darkangel: http://hotpink.bikeshed.org/
Sorry, I was disconnected.
This HTML WG decision process doesn't seem to work terribly well at resolving conflicts
If a decision is made one way, then the WHATWG spec ignores it and does the other thing

If the decision goes the other way, then people start repeating all their arguments about the topic and object to the decision and to the decision process and to the decision makers and want to reopen or escalate the issue
Why can't we all just get along?
expenses done
darkangel, iirc, something like that
annevk5: cool.
Philip`, because we disagree about the way specifications should be written on a rather fundamental level?
darkangel, .e.g http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/WD-html5-20080610/interactive-elements.html#datagrid has an old draft
darkangel, http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-html5-20090423/interactive-elements.html#datagrid is the latest version that includes it
darkangel, will prolly come back at some point
darkangel, when most other controls are somewhat stable
annevk5: I hope so.
Philip`, sounds utopical
Philip`: We can't get along because we can't get along
Will an editor control be added in future? (designMode is rather painful)
there's vague plans to make contenteditable work
first by fixing dom range
then by step-by-step fixing the interoperability holes
there's a couple of people working on something I believe, but nothing concrete just yet
I assumed we couldn't get along because HTMLWG is the contiuation of a generations-long holy war, the origins of which have been lost in the mists of time
It's mostly just because people are wrong on the internet
Of course it has become less serious now it takes the form of stiffly worded letters
rather than bloody battles in the desert
But still
annevk5: Thank you.

I'm surprised the default timezone for datetime is UTC, I would have thought it'd be more user-friendly to let the user enter times in their own timezone. (I realise the UA can make that possible, just think it should be the default).
it is in UTC for servers, not users
if you want local time for servers, use datatime-local
datetime-local*

Hey guys, I'm having a weird WebSocket issue right now. Works perfectly from everywhere else I tried it. But from this specific place I am it doesn't. For some reason, I can't connect to a remote websocket. But if I run it locally, I can connect just fine. What could cause that? ISP? Router? Firewall? I thought it was supposed to passthrough without any issue :)
jeromegn: Wrong channel me-thinks.
hmm
right channel me-thinks
thinks firewall issue
hmm
At first I thought it was that option on the router: "Block all outgoing connection requests"
but disabling it didn't help.

annevk5: I kinda misread the spec, but it does only say "may" -- "User agents may display the date and time in whatever time zone is appropriate for the user." maybe that should be "should", or maybe all UAs will do it anyway. :)
jeromegn, use some kind of network analyzer?
annevk5: I'll look that up
darkangel, just use the UA with the behavior you prefer :)
jeromegn, if you don't any, i've used wireshark with some success, but mostly for http traffic but it should do everything
have any*
hehe, first result on google, I'm going to try it out
annevk5: Will there be a visual indication of the TZ?
darkangel, depends on the UA
annevk5: Okay.
our implementation is not very nice; data:text/html,<input type=datetime> just says UTC for me
but then we haven't given it much UI polish, it was mostly to show the XForms types it could work
Speaking of xforms, I haven't heard much about that lately
it's all in the verticals
hard to spot
annevk5: Hmm ... small bug: if you select the hour and click up/down, it will increment/decrement once and then lose focus, so additional clicks will affect the minutes instead.
ugh
we are making some progress now in making changes though, so hopefully that's included too
is not closely involved in the UI fixing
+1 for actually implementing datetime. ;)
annevk5: what should I be looking for after filtering my websocket port in wireshark? I see a few entries but all that data is a little out of my league
it looks like this... I did twice "new WebSocket": http://cl.ly/6e2920fc6e5abdf3594b
jeromegn, when click one of those lines you get the data flow
but I'm not quite familiar how one finds a failure, though you could compare the two stacks of it working and not working I suppose
oh my
took hours for a ridiculous problem
Peter`, what does this do in IE

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cstyle%3E%20img%20{%20%20}%20%3C%2Fstyle%3E%0A%3Cimg%20src%3Dimage%20onload%3Dinit%28this%29%3E%0A%3Cscript%3E%0Afunction%20init%28i%29%20{%0A%20w%28i.x%29%3B%20w%28i.y%29%0A}%0A%3C%2Fscript%3E
could you give me the html snippet? IE says the URL cannot be opened
Peter`, ^
thank you
even better is this one
rendering mode: BackCompat
document has no title
log: undefined
log: undefined
and then click
ooh
same, but four times undefined
so it's a WebKit/Firefox thing that is biting us
maybe it can still be fixed
wadda you say Ms2ger?
cc me ;)
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=587021
cleaning up the web platform
two members at the time
Thanks
at one point I should go through all "interfaces" of all browsers and study the non-intersection
wishes we could kill lowsrc too
jgraham: How do you say "I don't speak Norwegian" in norwegian?
finds that that is a very useful phrase to have in any language.
TabAtkins: jeg snakker ikke norsk :]
And how do I pronounce that?
yay snacker icky narsque? i dunno. i just live in norway :)
Haha, sounds fun to say.
Norwegian always sounds disturbingly upbeat.
kling, TabAtkins, it's pronounced more like: yay snakker ikka norsk
All right, hopefully I can avoid having to talk norwegian at anybody until I can say it in front of a friendly native.
agrees that's a useful thing to know
I can only say it in French, though.
I got it in German.
You can only say you don't speak Norwegian in French?
And spanish, I guess.
sighs.  He knew someone would catch that awkward phrasing.
Workshiva, no, I can say that in English, Hebrew, or French (if I look up the word for "Norwegian" in Hebrew and French).
"Sprekken sie deutsch nicht", and "No hablo espanol".
Oh, I guess I can do Spanish too.
(Though I've been told the german is slightly wrong?)
Kind of easy to learn Spanish in Manhattan, just look at all the ads.
... very wrong
No idea the german version, but spanish's just missing the "ï¿½"
Well then, it serves its purpose of indicating that I can't speak german.
The German one sounds like... a weird "You don't speak German"
KaOSoFt: Yeah, I can't easily express that letter on this keyboard.
Well, I have an Android phone, so I can say it in any language supported by the voice version of Google Translate.
Possibly an awkward "Please don't speak German"
TabAtkins- Alt + 164
KaOSoFt, on Windows, maybe.
KaOSoFt: Your windows key combinations do nothing for me!
Also, that looks like it's a Windows-1252 code point.
What are you on: Linux, Macintosh?
(if I remember the numbers right)
linux
Yeah, I sometimes have problems with that on Arch.
Ctrl-Shift-uF1 on GNOME.
Ã±
Hmm... never thought about it, but there certainly should be a way to do those extra characters on console (Linux).
Ctrl-Shift-uXXXX works in GNOME, generally.
Except in some programs where some letters break because they're bound to something else.
(Like Opera)
Sigh.  If you're going to replace the native checkboxes with js-driven images, at least make sure your images are *pretty*.

So, it seems like Oracle is suing Google because technically the Java patent grants didn't apply to modified versions.  Now, why is it that everyone is calling the VP8 implementation open-source when the patent grant doesn't cover modified versions?

Actually, I seem to explicitly remember someone from Mozilla objecting on www-font to use of font compression with field-of-use restrictions on the relevant patent licenses.  Apparently that wasn't an overriding concern when it came to VP8.
software patents--
TabAtkins: myself and jgraham live/work in Sweden. Our Norwegian is, uh, bad.
TabAtkins: Also, you'll get by fine with just English
You guys don't work in the oslo office?
i'll be presenting on websockets at JavaZone in Oslo next month.
w00t!
TabAtkins: Nah, in the LinkÃ¶ping office
Ah, kk.
TabAtkins: Where all the cool stuff like Carakan happens ;P
TabAtkins: This is why it's somewhat notable both of us being in Oslo for the week of the CSS WG meeting
Was that just accidental, or were you guys coming down on purpose?
TabAtkins: In my case at least, I was going to be in Oslo some time this month anyway, and it made some sort of sense for it to be that week. He's primarily coming for it.
(made sense for it to be that week because of the meeting, that is)
Yeah.
(What I've been working on for the majority of my time since Carakan shipped in March is with a team which is completely in Oslo, except me)
Hixie: is it possible to put a challenge towards the IETF mailing list?
a challenge that is: every time they propose a new change to the protocol of websockets that they implement a working reference implementation which has a clean-ish API?
because I'm sure it's far easier to send an email than what it is to write some code to show your point.
